comments.content: Agree odd, but none of the other options makes sense.

discussion.content: Seems like ARO is redundant, since it is already calculated into the ALE

questions.question_text:
A legacy web application, which is being used by a hospital, cannot be upgraded for 12 months. A new vulnerability is found in the legacy application, and the networking team is tasked with mitigation. Middleware for mitigation will cost $100,000 per year. Which of the following must be calculated to determine ROI?
(Choose two.)

choices.A: Replace code with Java-based type checks
choices.D: Canonicalize input into string objects before validation

questions.question_text:
A security engineer is assisting a developer with input validation, and they are studying the following code block:
//IMG//

The security engineer wants to ensure strong input validation is in place for customer-provided account identifiers. These identifiers are ten-digit numbers. The developer wants to ensure input validation is fast because a large number of people use the system.
Which of the following would be the BEST advice for the security engineer to give to the developer?

discussion.content:
"Verifying the format of an item using tools such as regular expressions can be used for some items (e-mail, SSNs, phone numbers, and so no). Numbers
can be checked with check digits, or limit checks (greater or less than a specific value)"

questions.question_text:
A project manager is working with a software development group to collect and evaluate user stories related to the organization's internally designed CRM tool.
After defining requirements, the project manager would like to validate the developer's interpretation and understanding of the user's request. Which of the following would BEST support this objective?

discussion.content:
Maybe not B. Design review ?
The CRM is up and running. It has already been designed, built, approved, and handed over. 
I am not sure if ongoing modifications are considered part part of the application's "design." The basic design is likely to stay the same. A few tweaks do not count as redesigning the application. Or do they?

questions.question_text:
A network printer needs Internet access to function. Corporate policy states all devices allowed on the network must be authenticated. Which of the following is the
MOST secure method to allow the printer on the network without violating policy?

discussion.content: Answer C sounds like gangs of fun... NOT!

choices.C: Have a help desk employee sign in to the printer every morning
choices.B: Require anyone trying to use the printer to enter their username and password
choices.A: Request an exception to the corporate policy from the risk management committee
choices.D: Issue a certificate to the printer and use certificate-based authentication

questions.question_text: The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) of an e-retailer, which has an established security department, identifies a customer who has been using a fraudulent credit card. The CISO calls the local authorities, and when they arrive on-site, the authorities ask a security engineer to create a point-in-time copy of the running database in their presence. This is an example of:

discussion.content:
Both of these answers are correct:
A. creating a forensic image 
C. following a chain of custody 
However: "in their presence" may be the key here. This creates a scenario where law enforcement can attest to the validity of the snapshot of the database, since they were present while it was created and will testify that it was not tampered with before they took custody of the image.
Therefore: "following a chain of custody" may be the best answer.
On the other hand "creating a forensic image" is following chain of custody, but it's more specific. This describes exactly how you are following the chain of custody.
Therefore: "creating a forensic image" may be the best answer.
Gotta love CompTIA. They seem more interested in creating trick questions than in actually testing your knowledge.
